questions.question_text: On Fig. 2.1, sketch the variation of the gravitational potential with distance x from the centre of the planet for values of x between R and 4R.

A satellite is in a geostationary orbit above the Earth. On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation of the gravitational potential due to the Earth at the location of the satellite for values of t between t = 0 and t = 24 hours.
Two parallel plates have p.d. V and separation d in vacuum. On Fig. 2.4, sketch the variation of the electric potential with distance from the positive plate.
State Newton’s law of gravitation.
A satellite orbits a uniform spherical planet in a circular orbit of period T at height h above the surface. By reference to forces, explain why the orbit is circular.
Use Newton’s law of gravitation to show that (h + B)^3 = (G A / 4π^2) T^2, where G is the gravitational constant and A and B are constants depending on the planet.
Using the gradient and intercept of the straight line in Fig. 1.1 (plot of T^{2/3} against h), determine numerical values and units for A and B.
Define gravitational potential at a point.
Explain why the gravitational potential at X is negative.
State an expression, in terms of Φ, for the gravitational potential at Y due to the planet.

Complete Table 1.1 by giving expressions, in terms of some or all of M, R and Φ, for (i) the gravitational field strength at each satellite due to the planet and (ii) the gravitational potential energy of each satellite.
Explain why the gravitational potential near to a point mass is negative.
A planet (uniform sphere) has gravitational potential φ at distance r. From the straight-line graph of φ versus 1/r, show that the planet’s mass is 8.8 × 10^25 kg.
The planet’s rotation period is 0.72 Earth days. A satellite remains above the same point on the surface. Using the mass in (b)(i), determine the orbital radius R of the satellite.
Satellite speed is 8400 m s–1 and mass is 1200 kg. Determine the additional energy required to move it from this orbit to infinity.

Two identical beakers, each of mass M, are attached to each other using string and suspended from a pulley, as shown in Fig. 1.1. The beakers are held at rest at a height h above a surface. Cooking oil of volume V is added to one of the beakers. The beakers are released so that the beaker with the oil begins to fall. The speed of the beaker as it reaches the surface is z. It is suggested that z is related to V by the relationship 2h / z^2 = 2M / (a b V + 1 b), where a and b are constants. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between z and V. Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment. Explain how the results could be used to determine values for a and b. In your plan you should include: the procedure to be followed; the measurements to be taken; the control of variables; the analysis of the data; and any safety precautions to be taken.

A block of modelling clay of mass M is attached to a string as shown in Fig. 2.1. A pellet travelling at speed u enters the block and causes the block to move through a vertical height h. The experiment is repeated for different values of M. It is suggested that h and M are related by the equation h = (g/u^2) M + (1/Z), where g is the acceleration of free fall and Z is a constant. A graph is plotted of 1/h on the y-axis against M on the x-axis. Determine expressions for the gradient and y-intercept.
Values of M and h are given in Table 2.1. Calculate and record values of 1/h (in cm^−1) in Table 2.1. Include the absolute uncertainties in 1/h.
Plot a graph of 1/h (cm^−1) against M / g. Include error bars for 1/h.
Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Determine the y-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of u and Z. Include appropriate units. Data: g = 981 cm s^−2.
Determine the percentage uncertainty in Z.
The experiment is repeated. Determine the mass M that gives a value of h of 25.0 cm.
Define gravitational potential at a point.
Treat the Moon as an isolated uniform sphere (mass 7.3×10^22 kg, radius 1.7×10^6 m). Calculate the gravitational potential at its surface and give a unit.

An isolated uniform spherical planet has potential φ at its surface. A particle of mass m is projected vertically upward with just enough energy to escape to infinity without further work. Give an expression, in terms of m and φ, for the gravitational potential energy EP at the surface.
Show that the escape speed v from the surface is v = √(–2φ).
Using (a)(ii) and (b)(ii), determine the minimum speed for a particle at the Moon’s surface to escape.
Hydrogen may be assumed to be an ideal gas. The mass of a hydrogen molecule is 3.34×10^–27 kg. Calculate the r.m.s. speed of a hydrogen molecule at 400 K.
The Moon’s surface reaches ≈400 K in direct sunlight. Using (c) and (d), suggest why the Moon does not have a hydrogen atmosphere.
State what is indicated by the direction of the gravitational field line at a point in a gravitational field.
Explain, with reference to gravitational field lines, why the gravitational field near Earth’s surface is approximately constant for small changes in height.

An isolated uniform sphere (mass M, radius R). Point P lies on a line through the centre at displacement x. Fig. 1.2 shows g vs x inside the sphere; g at the surface has magnitude Y. Determine Y in terms of M and R, identifying any other symbols used.
Explain why, at the surface, the sign of g is always opposite to the sign of x.
Complete Fig. 1.2 to show the variation of g with x for |x| up to 3R when P is outside the sphere.

A wooden cube of mass A is placed on an inclined plane and attached by a string over a pulley to a hanging cylinder of mass B. The plane makes an angle θ to the horizontal. The cylinder is released and the time t to fall a distance d is measured. It is suggested that 2d/t^2 = −(A H sinθ)/(A + B) − (A K)/(A + B), where H and K are constants. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between t and θ. Draw a diagram of the arrangement, explain the procedure, measurements, control of variables, data analysis to determine H and K, and any safety precautions.
Define gravitational potential at a point.
Artemis is a spherical isolated planet. From Fig. 1.1 (φ vs distance x), the radius is 4800 km. Determine the value of φ on the surface of Artemis.
Show that the mass of Artemis is 2.55 × 10^24 kg.
Calculate the gravitational field strength g on the surface of Artemis.
A satellite is in an equatorial orbit above Artemis at a height where φ = −0.65 × 10^7 J kg^−1. Calculate the period, in hours, of rotation of Artemis.
State one similarity and one difference between gravitational potential due to a point mass and electric potential due to a point charge.
State Newton’s law of gravitation.
A satellite is in a circular orbit around a planet of mass M (uniform sphere). The orbital radius is R and the period is T. Use Newton’s law of gravitation to show that 4π^2 R^3 = G M T^2.

The Earth is a uniform sphere of mass 5.98 × 10^24 kg and radius 6.37 × 10^6 m. A geostationary satellite orbits the Earth. Use the expression in (b) to determine the height of the satellite above the Earth’s surface.
Another satellite has the same orbital radius and period as in (c). Calculate the angular speed of the satellite. Give a unit with your answer.
Despite having the same period, the orbit is not geostationary. Suggest two ways the orbit could differ from that in (c).
Define gravitational field.
Define electric field.
State one similarity and one difference between the gravitational potential due to a point mass and the electric potential due to a point charge.
An isolated uniform conducting sphere has mass M and charge Q. The gravitational field strength at the surface is g and the electric field strength is E. Show that M/Q = α gE, where α is a constant.
Show that the numerical value of α is 1.35 × 10^20 kg^2 C–2.

Assuming the Earth is a uniform conducting sphere of mass 5.98 × 10^24 kg and carries a charge of –4.80 × 10^5 C evenly distributed on the surface, use (b) to determine the electric field strength at the Earth’s surface. Give a unit with your answer.
State how the direction of the electric field at the Earth’s surface compares with the direction of the gravitational field.
On Fig. 1.2, draw labelled arrows to show the two forces acting on the ball.
Describe how the forces acting on the ball cause its acceleration to be centripetal.
The ball moves in a circle of radius 0.15 m. Show that the speed of the ball is 1.4 m s–1.
Calculate the angular speed ω of the ball.
The speed of the ball is increased. Explain why the radius of the circular path of the ball increases.
Define the radian.
For the instant shown in Fig. 1.1, draw an arrow labelled V showing the direction of the velocity of the modelling clay.
For the same instant, draw an arrow labelled A showing the direction of the acceleration of the modelling clay.
The disc radius is 9.3 cm. The centre of gravity of the clay is 1.2 cm from the rim and moves at 0.68 m s–1. Calculate the angular speed ω of the disc.
Calculate the acceleration a of the centre of gravity of the modelling clay.

A second piece of modelling clay with larger mass is attached as in Fig. 1.2. Complete Table 1.1 by ticking whether angular speed, linear speed and acceleration are less/same/greater for the second piece compared with the first.
Define the radian.

The minute hand of a clock completes one revolution every hour. A small piece of modelling clay is attached with its centre of gravity at distance L from the fixed end (Fig. 1.1). Calculate the angular speed ω of the minute hand.
During 1400 s, the clay’s centre of gravity moves a total distance of 0.44 m. Calculate the angle turned by the minute hand.
Determine the distance L.
Calculate the magnitude of the centripetal acceleration of the clay.
Explain, using your answer to (c)(iii), why the variation with time of the magnitude of the force exerted by the minute hand on the clay is negligible over one revolution.

A 0.29 kg steel sphere hangs from a vertical spring. In equilibrium the centre is 8.5 cm below the top. The sphere is then moved so it describes a horizontal circle; the distance from the centre to the top is now 10.8 cm. Explain, with reference to the forces on the sphere, why the spring is longer in circular motion.
The angle between the spring and the vertical is 27°. Show that the radius r of the circle is 4.9 cm.
Show that the tension in the spring is 3.2 N.
The spring obeys Hooke’s law. Calculate the spring constant, in N cm–1.
Use your values to determine the centripetal acceleration of the sphere.
Calculate the period of the circular motion of the sphere.
Define specific latent heat.
Show that the magnitude of the work done on the substance when it vaporises at atmospheric pressure is 1.7 kJ.
Calculate the thermal energy Q, in kJ, supplied to cause the vaporisation.
Use your answer in (b)(ii) to determine the specific latent heat of vaporisation LV in kJ kg–1.
Suggest and explain whether the specific latent heat of fusion LF is likely to be less than, the same as, or greater than the value of LV found in (b)(iii).
Define specific heat capacity.
Two metal blocks X and Y are placed in thermal contact at t = 0. From Fig. 2.1 (temperature vs time), state three conclusions (qualitative or quantitative) about their thermal behaviour.
Given (mass of Y)/(mass of X) = 1.3 and c_Y = 901 J kg^–1 K^–1, determine the specific heat capacity of the metal in block X.
State the magnitude and unit of absolute zero on the thermodynamic temperature scale.
Explain why temperature measured using a laboratory liquid-in-glass thermometer does not give a measurement of thermodynamic temperature.
Explain how Fig. 2.2 shows that platinum is a suitable metal for use in a resistance thermometer.
Suggest a reason why a platinum resistance thermometer is not suitable for measuring a rapidly changing temperature.
Suggest a type of thermometer that is suitable for measuring a rapidly changing temperature.

A negative temperature coefficient thermistor may be used as a type of resistance thermometer. State one way in which the variation with temperature of the resistance of a thermistor differs from that of a platinum wire.
State the reason why two objects that are at the same temperature are described as being in thermal equilibrium.
Using Fig. 3.1 (density vs temperature), suggest why mercury is suitable for measuring temperature between 0 °C and 100 °C.
Suggest why water is not suitable for measuring temperature over this range using density variation.
A 120 g liquid in a 42 g beaker (c = 0.84 J g–1 K–1) is heated at 810 W. From Fig. 3.2 (temperature vs time), state the boiling temperature of the liquid.
Determine the specific heat capacity of the liquid in J g–1 K–1, using Fig. 3.2 and the given data.

The experiment is repeated with water (same mass and power). The specific heat capacity of water is approximately twice that of the liquid and its boiling temperature is 100 °C. On Fig. 3.2, sketch the temperature–time graph for water between t = 0 and 60 s.

A graph is plotted of V on the y-axis against θ on the x-axis for trapped air heated in a cylinder. It is suggested that pV = Yk (θ + Z), where k is the Boltzmann constant, p is the atmospheric pressure, and Y and Z are constants. Determine expressions for the gradient and y-intercept.

Values of θ and h are given in Table 2.1. The cylinder diameter is d = (27.9 ± 0.1) mm. The volume is V = πd^2h / 4. Calculate and record values of V / 10^–5 m^3 in Table 2.1. Include the absolute uncertainties in V.
Plot a graph of V / 10^–5 m^3 against θ / °C. Include error bars for V.
Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Determine the y-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of Y and Z. Include appropriate units. Data: p = (1.01 ± 0.01) × 10^5 Pa; k = 1.38 × 10^–23 J K^–1.
Determine the percentage uncertainty in Y.
The experiment is repeated. Determine the temperature θ that gives a value of h of 60.0 mm.
State what is meant by the term thermal equilibrium.

P and Q start at the same temperature. P (0.54 kg, c = 390 J kg–1 K–1) and Q (0.37 kg, c = 910 J kg–1 K–1) are insulated from surroundings. P is supplied with 24 kJ and both return to the same temperature. Determine the change in temperature ΔT of Q.
At constant pressure 1.6 × 10^5 Pa, the volume–temperature (°C) graph of nitrogen is shown. The temperature increases from 0 °C to 210 °C. Determine the work done on the gas.
Determine the number N of molecules of nitrogen gas.
The mass of a nitrogen molecule is 4.7 × 10–26 kg. Calculate the r.m.s. speed of a nitrogen molecule at 210 °C.
State three of the basic assumptions of the kinetic theory of gases.
Explain how molecular movement causes the pressure exerted by a gas.
From Fig. 4.1 and Fig. 4.2 (〈c^2〉 vs T and pV vs T for gases X and Y), state three conclusions about the gases and their samples. Conclusions may be qualitative or quantitative.
State what is meant by the Avogadro constant.
State the relationship between the Avogadro constant NA, the molar gas constant R and the Boltzmann constant k.

Two samples X and Y of ideal gases are both at temperature T. X: volume V, N molecules (mass m each). Y: volume 2V, 2N molecules (mass 2m each). Complete Table 3.1 with expressions (in symbols given and constants) for pressure, amount of substance, mean-square speed, and internal energy for each sample.
The temperature of sample X is varied. On Fig. 3.1, sketch the variation with thermodynamic temperature of the r.m.s. speed of the molecules.
With reference to thermal energy, state what is meant by two objects being in thermal equilibrium.
Two cylinders X and Y each contain an ideal gas and are in thermal equilibrium. For cylinder X (0.740 mol, V = 0.0260 m^3, p = 1.20 × 10^5 Pa), show that the temperature is 234 °C.
For cylinder Y (V = 0.0430 m^3, p = 2.90 × 10^5 Pa), determine the number N of molecules. Explain your reasoning.
The gas in X has molecular mass four times that in Y. Explain how the r.m.s. speed of molecules in X compares with that in Y.
State what is meant by an ideal gas.
Use one of the basic assumptions of the kinetic theory to explain what can be deduced about the potential energy associated with the random motion of molecules in an ideal gas.
A sample of 0.26 m^3 of an ideal gas is at pressure 2.0 × 10^5 Pa and temperature 290 K. Determine the number N of molecules of the gas.
Determine the average translational kinetic energy EK of one molecule of the gas.
Determine the internal energy of the gas. Explain your reasoning.
The volume V of the gas is now varied, keeping its pressure constant. On Fig. 3.1, sketch the variation with V of the internal energy U of the gas.
tags: U vs V at const p

questions.question_text: In pV = (1/3)Nm〈c^2〉, state the meaning of N, m and 〈c^2〉.
Use the ideal-gas equation to show that the average translational KE per molecule is EK = (3/2)kT.
A star’s surface gas (ideal) has r.m.s. speed 9300 m s–1; molecule mass 3.34×10^–27 kg. Determine the surface temperature (3 s.f.).
Observed radiant flux intensity at distance 4.16×10^16 m is 2.52×10^–8 W m–2. Calculate the luminosity of the star (with unit).
Determine the radius of the star.
Using kinetic-theory assumptions, suggest why the high-pressure gas at a star’s surface is unlikely to behave ideally in practice.

Air is trapped in a transparent cylinder of diameter d with a movable piston. The distance from the base to the piston is h. The cylinder is placed in water at temperature θ. After the piston stops moving, h is measured and the trapped air volume is V = (π d^2 h) / 4. It is suggested that pV = Y k (θ + Z), where p is atmospheric pressure and k is the Boltzmann constant. A graph of V (y-axis) against θ (x-axis) is plotted. Determine expressions for the gradient and the y-intercept.
Given θ and h in Table 2.1 and d = (27.9 ± 0.1) mm, calculate and record V / 10^–5 m^3 for each row using V = (π d^2 h)/4. Include absolute uncertainties in V.
Plot a graph of V / 10^–5 m^3 (y-axis) against θ / °C (x-axis). Include error bars for V.
Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Determine the y-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine values of Y and Z. Include appropriate units. Data: p = (1.01 ± 0.01) × 10^5 Pa; k = 1.38 × 10^–23 J K^–1.
Determine the percentage uncertainty in Y.
The experiment is repeated. Determine the temperature θ that gives a value of h = 60.0 mm.
State what is meant by an ideal gas.
State the temperature, in degrees Celsius, of absolute zero.
A sealed vessel contains 0.0424 kg of an ideal gas at 227 °C. The pressure is 1.37 × 10^5 Pa and the volume is 0.640 m^3. Calculate the number of molecules in the vessel.
Calculate the mass of one molecule of the gas.
Calculate the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed v of the molecules.
The gas is cooled gradually to absolute zero. On a T–axis from 0 to 500 K, sketch the variation of the r.m.s. speed with thermodynamic temperature T.
State two of the basic assumptions of the kinetic theory of gases.

An ideal gas (amount n) is initially at state X (pressure 2p, volume V). It is cooled at constant volume to Y (pressure p), then heated at constant pressure to Z (volume 2V), and finally returns isothermally to X. Determine an expression for the temperature T at X in terms of n, p and V (identify any additional symbols).
On Fig. 4.1, sketch the p–V variation for the three changes. Label Y and Z (X is given).

During Y→Z the increase in internal energy is U. During Z→X the work done on the gas is W. Complete Table 4.1 to give, for each change, the increase in internal energy, the thermal energy transferred to the gas and the work done on the gas in terms of p, V, U and W.
State what is meant by the frequency of an alternating current.
For I = 3.5 sin(40πt) A in a 680 Ω resistor, show that the period is 50 ms.
On Fig. 8.1, sketch the variation of I with t between t = 0 and t = 100 ms.
Determine the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) current in the resistor.
Using data from (b), including your answer in (b)(iii), show by calculation that the mean power in the 680 Ω resistor is half of the peak power.
A circuit provides an output voltage VOUT across a load resistor R from an alternating input VIN (Fig. 7.1). State the purpose of the circuit.
From Fig. 7.2 (VOUT vs t) and R = 370 Ω, show that the maximum power dissipated in R is 0.22 W.
On Fig. 7.3, sketch the variation with time of the power P dissipated in R.
Calculate the mean power dissipated in R.
The circuit is disconnected and R is connected directly across the power supply. Explain, without calculation, how the mean power now dissipated in R compares with the answer in (b)(iii).
An electron’s mean position in a metal rod oscillates with SHM when an alternating voltage is applied. From Fig. 4.1 (x vs t), determine the amplitude.
Determine the angular frequency of the oscillations.
Use (a)(i) and (a)(ii) to show that the maximum drift speed v0 is 1.1×10^–7 m s–1.

The rod has cross-sectional area 4.3 cm^2 and conduction-electron density 8.5×10^28 m^–3. Assuming all electrons oscillate in phase with the same amplitude as Fig. 4.1, use (a)(iii) to calculate the maximum current I0.
On Fig. 4.2, sketch I versus t for 0 ≤ t ≤ 0.40 μs, showing ±I0.
Using (a)(ii) and (b)(i), determine an expression for I(t) (I in A, t in s).
Determine the r.m.s. current in the rod.
A current I through a resistor R varies with time as in Fig. 7.2 (period T). Determine the power P in the resistor when the current is in the negative direction.
Determine P when the current is in the positive direction.
On Fig. 7.3, sketch P vs t for 0 to 2.0T and label the power axis with a suitable scale.
Use (b) to determine an expression for the mean power ⟨P⟩ in terms of I0 and R.
Determine the r.m.s. current Ir.m.s. in terms of I0 and R.
Four diodes in a bridge rectifier produce rectification of a sinusoidal input VIN. (i) State the name of the type of rectification produced by a bridge rectifier.
(ii) Complete the circuit diagram by adding the three missing diodes, correctly connected.
(iii) Indicate with an arrow the direction of current in the load resistor R.
VIN has amplitude V0 and period T. On the provided axes, sketch VOUT vs t for 0 ≤ t ≤ 2.0T.
On axes of P vs t, sketch the power dissipated in R between t = 0 and t = 2.0T.
Suggest, with a reason, how the r.m.s. value of VOUT compares with the r.m.s. value of VIN.
In the half-wave rectifier circuit of Fig. 5.1 producing VOUT across a 14 kΩ resistor, add the correct symbol and connection for the missing component.
State the effect on VOUT of including capacitor C in the circuit.
Using Fig. 5.2 for VIN(t), determine the frequency of VIN.
Show that the time constant τ for the discharge of C through 14 kΩ is 0.038 s.
Calculate the capacitance of C. Give a unit with your answer.
The circuit is modified for full-wave rectification. Suggest, with a reason, how VOUT now varies with time when VIN is as in Fig. 5.2.

Fig. 1.1 shows a coil made from resistance wire. The coil is placed in cooking oil of mass m. The total length of the resistance wire in the oil is L. A potential difference V is applied to the coil. The temperature of the oil increases by Δθ in time t. It is suggested that Δθ is related to L by the relationship (A t V^2) / L = m K Δθ + Z, where A is the cross-sectional area of the wire, and K and Z are constants. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between Δθ and L. Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment. Explain how the results could be used to determine values for K and Z. In your plan you should include: the procedure to be followed; the measurements to be taken; the control of variables; the analysis of the data; and any safety precautions to be taken.

Fig. 1.1 shows a small solid metal cylinder of mass m, length L and diameter d. The cylinder is heated to a uniform temperature. The cylinder is then removed from the heat source and the cylinder is wrapped in an insulating material. The temperature of the room is TR. At time t after the cylinder starts to cool, the surface temperature of the cylinder is TC. It is suggested that TC is related to t by the relationship (TC – TR) = Z e^(−UAt / (m c)) where A is the total surface area of the cylinder, c is the specific heat capacity of the metal, and U and Z are constants. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between TC and t. Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment. Explain how the results could be used to determine values for U and Z. In your plan you should include: the procedure to be followed; the measurements to be taken; the control of variables; the analysis of the data; any safety precautions to be taken.
State what is meant by the internal energy of a system.
With reference to molecular kinetic and potential energies, describe and explain how the internal energy changes when a gas is heated at constant volume so that its temperature increases.
With reference to molecular energies, describe and explain how the internal energy changes when a wire is stretched within its elastic limit at constant temperature.
By referring to both kinetic energy and potential energy, explain what is meant by the internal energy of an ideal gas.

A fixed mass of ideal gas at 20 °C is sealed in a cylinder with a freely moving piston. Initial volume is 1.24 × 10^–4 m^3. Heating increases the volume by 5.20 × 10^–5 m^3 at atmospheric pressure 1.01 × 10^5 Pa. Calculate the work done by the gas.
Calculate the final thermodynamic temperature of the gas.
The gas mass is 16 g. The net thermal energy transferred to the gas in this expansion is 960 J. Calculate the specific heat capacity c at this pressure.

The gas is returned to the starting temperature. With the piston fixed, thermal energy is supplied to reach the same final temperature as in (b). Using the first law, suggest and explain how the specific heat capacity for this situation compares with the value in (b)(iii).
State what is meant by the internal energy of a system.
Use the first law of thermodynamics to explain what happens to the internal energy of a spring when it is stretched at constant temperature within its elastic limit.
Use the first law to explain what happens to the internal energy of a sample of water when it evaporates from a rain puddle on a hot day.
Define specific heat capacity.

An ideal gas (mass 0.35 kg) is heated at constant pressure 2.0×10^5 Pa. Its internal energy rises by 7600 J; volume increases 0.038→0.063 m^3 and temperature rises by 56 °C. Show that the magnitude of the work done on the gas is 5000 J.
Explain whether the work done on the gas is positive or negative.
Determine the magnitude of the thermal energy q transferred to the gas.
Calculate the specific heat capacity of the gas for this (constant-pressure) process. Give a unit.

The gas is heated at constant volume with the same increase in internal energy as in (b). Using the first law, explain whether the specific heat capacity for this process is less than, the same as, or greater than that in (b)(iv).

An electric pump is placed in a container of liquid. A model wind turbine is connected to the pump by a cable, as shown in Fig. 1.1. The turbine is placed in moving air. As the turbine blades turn, electricity is generated and the pump pushes liquid through a vertical pipe. The frequency of rotation of the turbine blades is f. The height the liquid moves is h. The mass per unit time of the liquid leaving the top of the pipe is Q. It is suggested that Q is related to f by the relationship Q g h = C + D f^3, where g is the acceleration of free fall, and C and D are constants. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between Q and f. Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment. Explain how the results could be used to determine values for C and D. In your plan you should include: the procedure to be followed; the measurements to be taken; the control of variables; the analysis of the data; any safety precautions to be taken.
State what is meant by an ideal gas.

A fixed amount of helium is rapidly compressed from 1.10 × 10^5 Pa, 540 cm^3 at 27 °C to 6.70 × 10^6 Pa, 30.0 cm^3 at 742 °C (no thermal energy exchange), as in Fig. 2.1. Show that the gas behaves as an ideal gas.
Using ΔU = q + W, explain why the temperature increases.
EK = 3/2 kT. Calculate the change in total kinetic energy of the helium molecules.
24.0 g of nitrogen gas at 27 °C is cooled to −196 °C and assumed to fully liquefy. Given c_gas = 1.04 kJ kg^−1 K^−1 and L_v = 199 kJ kg^−1, determine the thermal energy removed, in kJ.
State the first law of thermodynamics and identify the meaning of any symbols used.

An ideal-gas cycle ABCDA is shown on a p–V diagram. Complete a table for changes A→B and B→C by indicating: change in internal energy (decrease/no change/increase) and work done on gas (negative/zero/positive).
Using the first law, describe and explain the energy transfers for one complete cycle ABCDA.
From Fig. 4.1, show that the angular frequency of the vibration of the surface is 4.2 × 10^7 rad s–1.
Determine the maximum acceleration a0 of the vibration of the surface.
The crystal may be modelled as a single mass of 2.4 × 10–4 kg vibrating as in Fig. 4.1. Calculate the total energy E of the vibrations.
The crystal is made from a piezoelectric material. Explain how the crystal is made to vibrate.
A parallel ultrasound beam is incident on a muscle–bone boundary. Using Table 4.1 (ρ and speed for muscle and bone), calculate the percentage of intensity transmitted at this boundary.
On Fig. 5.1, draw an arrow from the centre of the sphere to represent the direction of the resultant force when in the shown position.
State the amplitude of the oscillations from Fig. 5.2.
Determine the angular frequency of the oscillations.
Calculate the total energy of the oscillations for the 0.15 kg sphere.
On Fig. 5.3, sketch the variation with displacement x of the kinetic energy EK of the sphere.
State what is meant by simple harmonic motion.
A block on a vertical spring oscillates. From Fig. 4.2 (v vs h), determine the amplitude (cm) of the oscillations.
Show that the angular frequency of the oscillations is 3.2 rad s–1.
Calculate the period T of the oscillations.
On Fig. 4.3, sketch the variation of height h with time t from 0 to 6.0 s, using the provided scale.

A student investigates the resonant frequency of a metal rod. The metal rod of length L is suspended from two rubber loops. A sensitive microphone with a cone is positioned at one end of the rod and attached to an oscilloscope (Fig. 2.1). The rod is hit gently with a hammer and the period T of the trace on the oscilloscope is determined. The experiment is repeated for different values of L. It is suggested that T and L are related by T = (2 L^n) / C, where C and n are constants. (a) A graph is plotted of lg T on the y-axis against lg L on the x-axis. Determine expressions for the gradient and y-intercept.
Values of L and T are given in Table 2.1. Calculate and record values of lg (L / cm) and lg (T / 10^–5 s) in Table 2.1. Include the absolute uncertainties in lg T.
(c)(i) Plot a graph of lg (T / 10^–5 s) against lg (L / cm). Include error bars for lg T.
(c)(ii) Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
(c)(iii) Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
(c)(iv) Determine the y-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
(d) Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of n and C. Include the absolute uncertainties in your values. You need not be concerned with units.
(e) The experiment is repeated. Determine the length L of the rod that gives a value of T of 0.10 ms.

A student investigates the sound from a horn attached to a car, as shown in Fig. 2.1. A microphone is placed at the side of the road and connected to a frequency meter. The car travels towards the microphone. The frequency f of the sound detected by the microphone is read from the frequency meter. The speed of the car is measured by two speed detectors. The two measurements of speed are v1 and v2. The average speed v of the car is determined from v1 and v2. The experiment is repeated for different speeds of the car. It is suggested that f and v are related by the equation f = f_s k / (k − v) where f_s is the frequency of the sound emitted by the horn and k is a constant. (a) A graph is plotted of 1/f on the y-axis against v on the x-axis. Determine expressions for the gradient and y-intercept.
(b) Values of v1, v2 and f are given in Table 2.1. Calculate and record values of v / m s–1 and 1/f / 10^–3 Hz–1 in Table 2.1. Include the absolute uncertainties in v.
(c)(i) Plot a graph of 1/f / 10^–3 Hz–1 against v / m s–1. Include error bars for v.
(c)(ii) Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
(c)(iii) Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
(c)(iv) Determine the y-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
(d)(i) Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of f_s and k. Include appropriate units.
(d)(ii) Determine the percentage uncertainty in k.
(e) The experiment is repeated. Determine the speed v that gives a value of f of 987.8 Hz.
A block of mass m oscillates vertically on a spring. The acceleration a varies with displacement x as in Fig. 4.2. Explain how Fig. 4.2 shows that the oscillations are simple harmonic.
Deduce an expression, in terms of some or all of m, A and Y, for the angular frequency ω.
Deduce an expression for the maximum speed v0 of the oscillations.
Deduce an expression for the energy E of the oscillations.
The period is 0.75 s and 3Y = 1.8 cm. Determine an expression for x in terms of time t (x in cm, t in s).
State what is meant by resonance.
Fig. 4.2 shows displacement vs time for a released ball on a string. State the name of the phenomenon illustrated by the decrease in the amplitude of the oscillations.
Explain the decrease with time of the amplitude of the oscillations of the ball.
Determine the frequency of the oscillations of the ball from Fig. 4.2.
The vibration generator is switched on and its frequency f is increased from 0 to 10 Hz. On Fig. 4.3, sketch the variation with f of the amplitude of the oscillations of the ball.

A thin cylindrical metal rod of length L is struck with a hammer so that a stationary sound wave is set up within the rod at its resonant frequency f. A microphone at the other end detects sound of the same frequency f. A number of rods of different lengths are available. It is suggested that 2 f L^n = E / ρ, where ρ is the density of the metal and E and n are constants. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between f and L. Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of equipment and explain how the results could be used to determine values for E and n. Include the procedure, measurements, control of variables, data analysis, and any safety precautions.

An object of mass 24 g rests on a vertical platform driven by an oscillator. The total energy of the oscillations is 2.2 × 10^–4 J and the object travels a total distance of 14 mm per oscillation. Calculate the angular frequency ω.
With frequency fixed, the amplitude is increased. Calculate the maximum amplitude so the object does not lose contact with the platform.
If the amplitude exceeds the value in (b)(i), state and explain the position in the oscillation where the object first loses contact with the platform.
Small sideways oscillations of a 0.81 kg sphere on a string (amplitude 0.036 m, period 3.0 s) are simple harmonic. State what is meant by simple harmonic motion.
Calculate the angular frequency of the oscillations.
Calculate the total energy of the oscillations.
Sphere is lowered into water, displaced to +0.036 m and released at t=0. Motion is critically damped. On Fig. 4.2, sketch x vs t for 0–6.0 s.
An object on a vertical spring oscillates in SHM. Fig. 3.2 shows E vs displacement x with lines P, Q, R. State which energy each of P, Q and R represents.
The object has mass 130 g. Determine the period of the oscillations.
State the cause of damping.

A light card is attached. With the same initial amplitude, the total energy decreases by 8.0% each cycle. Determine the decrease in total energy, in mJ, by the end of the first 6 complete oscillations.
State, with a reason, the type of damping introduced by the card.
A steel sphere oscillates vertically on a spring. Its velocity v (cm s–1) varies with displacement x (cm) as v = ± 9.7 (11.6 − x^2)^{1/2}. Calculate the frequency of the oscillations.
Show that the amplitude of the oscillations is 3.4 cm.
Calculate the maximum acceleration a0 of the sphere.
On axes of a vs x, sketch the variation of the acceleration a with displacement x (scales indicated).
Describe, without calculation, the interchange between potential and kinetic energy during the oscillations.

A student investigates the circuit in Fig. 2.1. A power supply of e.m.f. Es (negligible internal resistance) is in series with three resistors each of resistance Z. A cell (e.m.f. E), an ammeter and a resistor R are connected in parallel across one of these resistors. The current I is measured for different values of R. It is suggested that I and R satisfy 3E − Es = I(3R + 2Z). (a) A graph is plotted of 1/I (y-axis) against R (x-axis). Determine expressions for the gradient and the y-intercept.
(b) Table 2.1 gives values of R (kΩ) and I (μA). Calculate and record 1/I in A^−1, including the absolute uncertainties in 1/I.
(c)(i) Plot a graph of 1/I (A^−1) against R (kΩ). Include error bars for 1/I.
(c)(ii) Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
(c)(iii) Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty.
(c)(iv) Determine the y-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty.
(d)(i) Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of E and Z. Include appropriate units. Data: Es = (2.20 ± 0.05) V.
(d)(ii) Determine the absolute uncertainty in E.
(e) The experiment is repeated. Determine the resistance R that gives I = 250 μA.
State Coulomb’s law.
On Fig. 6.1, draw field lines to represent the electric field outside the positively charged isolated hollow conducting sphere.
From Fig. 6.2 (E vs x), determine the radius, in cm, of the sphere.
Calculate the charge on the sphere.
Suggest an explanation for the fact that the electric field inside the sphere is zero.
State the relationship between electric field and electric potential.

Two charged isolated insulating spheres X and Y are near each other (Fig. 5.1). Point P lies on the line of centres. Explain why, at P, total electric potential and resultant electric field cannot both be zero simultaneously.
Charges on spheres X and Y have magnitudes Q and 2Q and may be treated as point charges. P is distance x from X; the potential at P is zero. Show that the distance y from Y is 2x.
State an expression for the electric field strength EX at P due to sphere X in terms of Q, x and ε0.
Hence determine an expression for the resultant electric field strength E at P due to both spheres.
Define electric potential at a point.

Two isolated charged metal spheres X and Y are 1.2 m apart (Fig. 5.1). Fig. 5.2 shows the total electric potential V at point P versus distance x from X. State three qualitative or quantitative conclusions about the spheres from Fig. 5.2.
A proton is held at rest at x = 0.60 m and released. Describe and explain, without calculation, its subsequent motion.
Define electric field.
Two parallel conducting plates in vacuum are separated by 6.7 cm with p.d. 430 V. On Fig. 5.1, draw four field lines to represent the electric field between the plates.
Determine the strength E of the electric field between the plates.
An electron enters the region between the plates at 2.6 × 10^7 m s–1. On Fig. 5.1, draw the path of the electron as it moves between and beyond the plates.
A uniform magnetic field is applied so the electron travels undeviated. Determine the direction of the magnetic field.
Explain, with reference to the forces exerted by the two fields on the electron, why the path of the electron is undeviated.
Determine the flux density B of the uniform magnetic field. Give a unit with your answer.

A power supply with negligible internal resistance is connected to six resistors each of resistance Z and a resistor R as shown. The ammeter reads current I. The experiment is repeated for different values of R. It is suggested that E = 3 I R + 4 I Z, where E is the e.m.f. of the supply. A graph is plotted of 1/I (y-axis) against R (x-axis). Determine expressions for the gradient and the y-intercept.
Values of R and I are given in Table 2.1. Calculate and record values of 1/I in A^−1 in the table, including the absolute uncertainties in 1/I.
Plot a graph of 1/I (A^−1) against R (kΩ). Include error bars for 1/I.
Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Determine the y-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of E and Z. Include appropriate units.
Determine the percentage uncertainty in Z.
The experiment is repeated. Determine the resistance R that gives a value of I of 0.10 mA.
State Coulomb’s law.
Two identical oil droplets in vacuum are 3.8×10^–6 m apart and exert a force of 6.3×10^–17 N on each other. Determine the charge on each droplet.
One droplet is placed between horizontal metal plates at 0 V and +1200 V separated by 5.2 cm (Fig. 5.1). The droplet is stationary and in equilibrium. State the sign of its charge.
On Fig. 5.1, draw four lines to represent the electric field between the plates.
Given the plate separation is 5.2 cm, determine the mass of the oil droplet.
Define electric potential at a point.

Two isolated charged spheres X and Y are 24 m apart. Fig. 5.1 shows V at point P vs distance x from X along the line of centres. State three qualitative or quantitative conclusions about the spheres from the graph.
A positively charged particle is placed at P where x = 12 m and released. Describe and explain its subsequent motion.
State Coulomb’s law.
Two charged spheres: X (+96 nC) on a stand; Y (+64 nC) suspended by a 1.2 m thread. Centres are 0.080 m apart horizontally (Fig. 4.1). On Fig. 4.2, draw and label all forces on Y.
Determine the mass of sphere Y.
Calculate the total electric potential energy between X and Y.
Between parallel plates P and Q (separation 18 mm) with 250 V across them, state the direction of the electric force on an electron entering the region.
Determine the magnitude of the electric force on the electron.
Explain why the electron does not follow a circular path.
Two capacitors C1 and C2 in series: Show that 1/C = 1/C1 + 1/C2.
Three identical capacitors (each C) in the network of Fig. 5.1 have Q–V graph shown in Fig. 5.2. Show that the equivalent C is 44 μF.
The charged network discharges through a 54 kΩ resistor. Determine the time constant τ of the circuit. Give a unit.
Determine the time taken for the discharge current to reduce to 15% of its initial value.
Define the capacitance of a parallel-plate capacitor.
On Fig. 7.1, sketch the variation of charge Q with p.d. for capacitor X as the p.d. increases from 0 to V.
Determine an expression, in terms of Q and V, for the work W done on capacitor X during charging. Explain your reasoning.

Capacitor Y (capacitance 3C) is connected to the fully charged capacitor X as shown. Complete Table 7.1 with expressions (in terms of Q and V) for the final p.d.s across, and the final charges on, the two capacitors.
State whether the total energy stored in the two capacitors is less than, the same as, or greater than the energy initially stored in capacitor X.
State what is meant by rectification of an alternating voltage.
State the difference between half-wave rectification and full-wave rectification.
Complete Fig. 6.1 to show a circuit that produces half-wave rectification of an alternating input VIN to give VOUT across resistor R.
State the purpose of the capacitor C in the circuit of Fig. 6.1.
For the square-wave input VIN of Fig. 6.2 and the output VOUT of Fig. 6.3, the maximum energy stored in the capacitor is 0.041 J. Show that the capacitance is 570 μF.
Determine the resistance R in the circuit.
Two capacitors X and Y are connected in series to a supply V. Capacitances are CX and CY. Derive an expression for the combined capacitance CT in terms of CX and CY, explaining your reasoning.
Two capacitors P and Q are in parallel on a supply V. CP = 200 μF; CQ varies 0→400 μF. When CQ = 0, total stored energy is 2.5 mJ. Show that V = 5.0 V.
Calculate the total energy (in mJ) stored when CQ has its maximum value.
On Fig. 6.2, sketch the variation of total stored energy E with CQ for 0 ≤ CQ ≤ 400 μF.
A capacitor C in series with resistor R has initial p.d. 12 V. At t = 0 the switch is closed and current I is recorded as in Fig. 6.2. Explain the shape of the I–t graph.
Use Fig. 6.2 to determine the resistance R.
Determine the time constant τ of the circuit.
Use your answers in (b) to determine the capacitance C.
Three capacitors 45 μF, 10 μF and 20 μF are connected as shown. Determine the total capacitance of the network in μF.
A 45 μF capacitor is charged as a supply rises from 8.0 V to 9.6 V. Calculate the increase in stored energy ΔE.
A sinusoidal a.c. supply feeds a bridge rectifier and load resistor. Complete the circuit by adding a capacitor to smooth the p.d. across the load.
From the graph of smoothed V versus t, determine the time constant of the smoothing circuit in ms.
A sinusoidal a.c. supply has maximum power 16 W. State the mean power when the output is full-wave rectified.
State the mean power when the output is half-wave rectified.

A student investigates the discharge of capacitors in the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1. The capacitors have capacitances CA and CB. The student closes the switch to charge the capacitors. The switch is opened and a stop-watch is started. The capacitors discharge through the resistor of resistance R. At a fixed time t the voltmeter reading V is recorded. The experiment is repeated for different values of CA and CB. For each combination of CA and CB, the combined capacitance C is calculated. It is suggested that C and V are related by the equation V = I0 R e^(−t/(CR)), where I0 is the initial current in the resistor. (a) A graph is plotted of ln V on the y-axis against 1/C on the x-axis. Determine expressions for the gradient and y-intercept.

(b) Values of CA, CB and V are given in Table 2.1. The relationship between C, CA and CB is 1/C = (CA + CB)/(CA CB). Calculate and record values of 1/C / 10^4 F^−1 and ln (V / V) in Table 2.1. Include the absolute uncertainties in ln (V / V).
(c)(i) Plot a graph of ln (V / V) against 1/C / 10^4 F^−1. Include error bars for ln (V / V).
(c)(ii) Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
(c)(iii) Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
(c)(iv) Determine the y-intercept of the line of best fit. Do not include the absolute uncertainty.
(d)(i) Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of R and I0. Include appropriate units. Data: t = (30 ± 1) s.
(d)(ii) Determine the percentage uncertainty in R.
(e) The experiment is repeated with the same value of t. Determine the combined capacitance C that gives a value of V of 1.20 V.
A capacitor C is initially at V = 8.0 V, then connected across a resistor R (Fig. 6.1). Fig. 6.2 shows V against charge Q during discharge. Show that the initial stored energy is 1.8 mJ.
Determine the capacitance of C and give a unit.
Fig. 6.3 shows –ln(V/8.0 V) versus t. Show that when t equals one time constant, –ln(V/8.0 V) = 1.0.
Determine the time constant τ of the circuit.
Calculate the resistance R.

In the circuit of two capacitors CP and CQ discharging through resistor R, it is suggested that ln(V/V0) = −T/(CR). A graph of T (y-axis) against C (x-axis) is plotted. Determine an expression for the gradient.

Given CP, CQ and two measurements of t in Table 2.1 and that the combined capacitance is C = (CP CQ)/(CP + CQ), calculate and record C / 10^−4 F and the mean time T / s for each row. Include absolute uncertainties in T.
Plot a graph of T / s (y-axis) against C / 10^−4 F (x-axis). Include error bars for T.
Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Given V0 = (4.8 ± 0.1) V and V = (2.4 ± 0.1) V, calculate ln(V/V0). Include the absolute uncertainty.
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (d), determine the value of R. Include an appropriate unit.
Determine the percentage uncertainty in R.
The experiment is repeated. Determine the value of C that gives T = 60.0 s. Include the absolute uncertainty.
Circuit of Fig. 5.1 charges a capacitor (12 V source, resistor R, two-way switch). From the graph of ln(Q/μC) vs t (Fig. 5.2), show that the capacitance is 1.5 μF.
Determine the resistance R.
Calculate the energy stored in the capacitor at t = 0.
A second identical resistor is connected in parallel with R. On Fig. 5.2, sketch ln(Q/μC) vs t for 0 ≤ t ≤ 5.0 s for the new discharge.
Two capacitors A (C) and B (3C) with a two-way switch S and e.m.f. V are arranged as shown. With S at X, B is uncharged. State expressions, in terms of V and C, for: (i) the initial charge QA on A,
(ii) the initial energy EA stored in A.
S is moved to Y. State and explain what happens to the charge that was initially on the plates of capacitor A.
Show that the final p.d. VB across B is VB = V/4. Explain your reasoning.
Determine an expression, in terms of V and C, for the decrease ΔE in the total energy stored in the capacitors after the switch is moved.

Two coils, P and Q, are placed close to each other, as shown in Fig. 1.1. A resistor of resistance R is connected in series with coil P. A changing magnetic flux of frequency f in coil P causes an electromotive force (e.m.f.) E to be induced across the terminals of coil Q. It is suggested that E is related to R by the relationship E = 2πf M ( V / (R + k) ), where V is the potential difference across the resistor and coil P, and k and M are constants. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between E and R. Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment. Explain how the results could be used to determine values for k and M. In your plan you should include: the procedure to be followed; the measurements to be taken; the control of variables; the analysis of the data; any safety precautions to be taken.
Velocity selector with plate p.d. V, separation d, and field B. Show that undeviated speed u = V/(Bd).
Positive ions (KE 4.1 × 10–17 J, mass 3.2 × 10–27 kg) pass undeviated when V = 980 V and d = 3.6 × 10–2 m. Determine B.
A proton passes undeviated. An alpha particle enters at the same speed. State how (a) predicts the alpha particle also passes undeviated.
By reference to Fig. 6.1 and to the forces on a positive ion, determine the direction of the magnetic field. Explain your reasoning.
The ions in (b) enter with greater kinetic energy. On Fig. 6.1, sketch the path of these ions.
State Faraday’s law of electromagnetic induction.
A metal rod accelerates uniformly in a uniform B-field (length l, flux density B). Fig. 7.2 shows the induced e.m.f. E vs time. Explain how Fig. 7.2 shows that E is proportional to the velocity v.
Use Faraday’s law to show that E = B l a t, where a is the acceleration of the rod.
The rod has length 0.45 m and acceleration 7.8 m s–2. Determine B.

A thin cylindrical bar magnet of length L and cross-sectional area A is attached to a block. An identical magnet is attached to a trolley (Fig. 1.1). The trolley is held so that the separation of the N poles of the two magnets is s. Point P is a distance D from the N pole of the magnet on the stationary trolley. The trolley is released and the speed v of the trolley at point P is determined using one light gate. It is suggested that v and s are related by the given relationship involving A, B (the magnetic flux density at the N pole), L, D, m (the trolley mass) and constants K and Q. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between v and s. Draw a diagram of the arrangement. Explain how the results would be used to determine K and Q, including: procedure, measurements, control of variables, analysis of data, and safety precautions.
For point X on the rim of the rotating wheel, determine the speed.
For point X, determine the centripetal acceleration.
State Lenz’s law of electromagnetic induction.
Show that the time taken for point X to complete one revolution is 45 ms.
Calculate the magnetic flux cut by spoke AX during one revolution of the wheel. Give a unit with your answer.
Determine the magnitude of the electromotive force (e.m.f.) induced across spoke AX.
Using Lenz’s law, explain whether the potential is higher at end A or end X of the spoke.
Define magnetic flux density.
A long straight wire carries current into the page (Fig. 7.1). On Fig. 7.1, draw four field lines for the magnetic field around the wire.
Two parallel identical wires X and Y carry currents into the page (Fig. 7.2). Explain why they exert magnetic forces on each other.
On Fig. 7.2, draw and label with F the direction of the magnetic force on wire X.
The current in X is double that in Y. State how the magnetic force on Y compares with that on X.
Both currents are now reversed. State, with a reason, the effect on the direction of the force on wire X.

A spring is attached to a strong cylindrical magnet of length L and cross-sectional area A. The magnet is placed on thin card on top of a magnetic sheet on the bench (Fig. 1.1). The thickness of the card is t. The magnetic flux density at one of the poles of the magnet is B. A force is applied upwards to the spring. The extension of the spring when the magnet just leaves the card is s. It is suggested that s is related to t by the relationship k s = (A L B Z) / t, where k is the spring constant of the spring and Z is a constant. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between s and t. Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment. Explain how the results could be used to determine a value for Z. In your plan include: the procedure, the measurements to be taken, the control of variables, the analysis of the data, and any safety precautions.
State Faraday’s law of electromagnetic induction.

A coil (340 turns, area 3.2 × 10^–4 m^2) rests in a uniform magnetic field parallel to its axis (Fig. 7.1). The field varies with time as in Fig. 7.2. Calculate the maximum magnetic flux through one turn.
Determine the maximum rate of change of magnetic flux linkage in the coil.
State the maximum induced e.m.f. V0 across the coil.
On Fig. 7.3, sketch the variation of induced e.m.f. V with t from 0 to 6.0 ms.
The variation follows V = A sin Bt. Determine A and B with units.
An object travels in a circle at constant speed. State two quantities that vary during the motion.
A charged particle (mass m, charge q) moves perpendicular to uniform B, describing a circle of period T and radius r. By considering magnetic force, show that B = (2πm)/(qT).
For an alpha particle with period 2.5 μs, calculate B.
A second alpha particle in the same field travels in a circle of radius 2r. State and explain how its period compares with that in (b)(ii).

The speed of the alpha particle in (b)(ii) is 1.1 × 10^6 m s–1. An electric field is applied so the particle now moves with constant velocity. Using your answer to (b)(ii), calculate the electric field strength E and give its unit.

A 64-turn coil C of cross-sectional area 0.71 cm^2 is moved along the axis inside a solenoid from position X to Y with constant solenoid current. Sketch the magnetic flux linkage in coil C versus position from X to Y.
Explain the shape of the line in (a)(i).

With coil C fixed at X, the solenoid’s magnetic flux density B at X varies with time as shown (from 0 to 4t, with values 0, 0.040 T, 0.080 T at t, 2t, 3t). Calculate the maximum magnetic flux linkage in coil C.
On axes provided, sketch the induced e.m.f. E in coil C from time 0 to 4t corresponding to the variation of B in (a)(iii).

A metal spring lies on a smooth table; its ends are connected to a d.c. power supply with flexible leads. The spring is not under tension. With reference to magnetic fields, describe and explain the change in the spacing between turns when the supply is first switched on.

Two coils, C and D, are placed with their axes on a straight line, as shown in Fig. 1.1. A resistor of resistance R is connected in series with coil C. A changing magnetic flux of frequency f in coil C causes an electromotive force (e.m.f.) E to be induced across the terminals of coil D. It is suggested that E is related to f by the relationship E = p f^q V / R, where V is the potential difference across the resistor and coil C, and p and q are constants. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between E and f. Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment. Explain how the results could be used to determine values for p and q. In your plan you should include: the procedure to be followed, the measurements to be taken, the control of variables, the analysis of the data, and any safety precautions to be taken.

A Hall probe uses a thin semiconductor slice of thickness x = 1.8 mm with carrier density 1.5×10^16 m^–3. With current 5.4 A and a uniform field B (Fig. 7.1, 7.2), show that when B = 4.0×10^–6 T the Hall voltage VH = 5.0 V.
On Fig. 7.3, sketch VH versus t for 0 ≤ t ≤ 0.080 s.
Probe replaced by a flat 3000-turn coil of area 3.4×10^–4 m^2, plane perpendicular to B(t) as in Fig. 7.2. Show that at t = 0.010 s the induced e.m.f. E = 2.0×10^–4 V.
On Fig. 7.4, sketch E versus t for 0 ≤ t ≤ 0.080 s.
Define magnetic flux density.
Electrons at 1.7×10^7 m s–1 enter a uniform field B = 4.8 mT; path shown in Fig. 6.1. State the direction of the magnetic field.
Show that the magnetic force on each electron is 1.3×10^–14 N.
On Fig. 6.1, draw an arrow to indicate the direction of the centripetal acceleration at entry point X.
Using (b)(ii), calculate the distance d between the incoming and outgoing paths of the electrons.
Electrons are replaced by positrons moving at 3.4×10^7 m s–1 along the same initial path. On Fig. 6.1, draw the path of the positrons through the field.

Two coils P and Q are placed close together. Coil P is in series with a resistor of resistance R and has an applied alternating magnetic flux of frequency f. An e.m.f. E is induced across the terminals of coil Q. It is suggested that E = 2π f M (V / (R + k)), where V is the potential difference across the resistor and coil P, and k and M are constants. Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between E and R. Draw a diagram of the arrangement, describe the procedure, measurements, control of variables, analysis to determine k and M, and state any safety precautions.
A Hall probe gives zero Hall voltage in one orientation but maximum when rotated. Explain these observations.
In VH = BI/(ntq), state the meaning of n.
Explain why a Hall probe is made from silicon rather than copper.

The probe reads 24 mV in B = 32 mT at a fixed angle. In a varying field (same angle), VH vs t is given in Fig. 6.1 (0–8.6 s). A coil with 780 turns and diameter 3.6 cm has its plane ⟂ field lines. Calculate the magnitude of the maximum e.m.f. induced in the coil between t = 0 and 8.6 s.
A heavy aluminium disc (radius 0.36 m) rotates with a vehicle wheel. A uniform magnetic field of flux density 0.17 T is switched on, perpendicular to the disc. (i) Define magnetic flux.
(ii) Calculate the magnetic flux through the disc. Give a unit with your answer.
The disc rotates at 25 rev s–1. Calculate the magnitude of the e.m.f. induced between axle and rim.

The axle and rim are connected to an external circuit that stores rotational energy for future use. Using Lenz’s law, determine whether the current in the disc is from rim to axle or axle to rim, and explain.
State what is meant by a magnetic field.
A long straight wire P carries current into the page. On Fig. 6.1, draw four field lines representing the magnetic field around P due to the current.
A parallel wire Q (5.0 A) carries current out of the page. The flux density at Q due to P is 2.6 mT. Calculate the magnetic force per unit length on Q due to P.
State the direction of the force exerted on wire Q by wire P.
The flux density at P due to Q is 1.5 mT. Determine the magnitude of the current in P and explain your reasoning.
State what is meant by a photon.
A laser emits red light when electrons drop between two levels with energy difference 1.96 eV. Calculate the wavelength.
Laser power is 1.0 × 10–2 W. Calculate the number of photons emitted per unit time.
Photons are incident normally on a surface. Half are absorbed and half reflected. Determine the average force exerted by the beam on the surface.

A student investigates the refraction of white light entering a transparent rectangular block. A narrow beam of light enters the block at the midpoint of one of the shorter sides. The angle of incidence θ is measured, as shown in Fig. 2.1. The distance d between the corner of the block and the point where the beam of light touches the boundary of the block is measured. The experiment is repeated for different values of θ. It is suggested that d and θ are related by the equation B / (B + d^2) = sin^2 θ / n^2, where B and n are constants. (a) A graph is plotted of d^2 on the y-axis against 1 / sin^2 θ on the x-axis. Determine expressions for the gradient and y-intercept.
Values of θ, 1 / sin^2 θ and d are given in Table 2.1. Calculate and record values of d^2 / cm^2 in Table 2.1. Include the absolute uncertainties in d^2.
(c)(i) Plot a graph of d^2 / cm^2 against 1 / sin^2 θ. Include error bars for d^2.
(c)(ii) Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
(c)(iii) Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
(c)(iv) Determine the y-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
(d)(i) Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of B and n. Include appropriate units.
(d)(ii) Determine the percentage uncertainty in n.
(e) The experiment is repeated. Determine the angle θ that gives a value of d of 30.0 cm.
Explain what the observation of an interference pattern shows about the nature of electrons.
Determine an expression, in terms of m, q and V, for the momentum p of an electron accelerated from rest through p.d. V.
The accelerating p.d. is increased. Describe and explain the effect on the interference pattern observed after the graphite crystal.
On Fig. 9.1, sketch the variation of momentum p with 1/λ for electrons accelerated through different values of V.
State the name of the quantity represented by the gradient of the line in Fig. 9.1.
A polished sheet of magnesium in vacuum emits electrons when illuminated by ultraviolet radiation. State the name of this phenomenon.
Emission requires a minimum frequency 8.8 × 10^14 Hz. Calculate the work-function energy of magnesium.
For ultraviolet radiation of frequency 1.1 × 10^15 Hz, calculate the maximum speed of emitted electrons.
The frequency f is varied from 8.0 × 10^14 Hz to 1.1 × 10^15 Hz. On Fig. 8.1, sketch the variation with f of the maximum kinetic energy E_MAX of the emitted electrons.
A photon has energy 3.11 × 10^–19 J. Calculate its momentum.
A 350 mW laser emits light of wavelength 640 nm. Determine the number of photons emitted in 1.0 s.
The laser beam is normally incident on a surface that absorbs all photons. Show that the force on the surface is F = P/c.
Monochromatic light is incident on metals with work functions given: tungsten 4.49 eV, magnesium 3.68 eV, potassium 2.26 eV. Explain the term threshold wavelength.
For the metals listed, calculate the largest threshold wavelength.
State what is meant by a photon.
Name the phenomenon in which electrons are emitted from a metal surface when illuminated by electromagnetic radiation.
It is observed that emission occurs only when the radiation frequency exceeds a threshold, irrespective of intensity. Explain how this supports the existence of photons.
For Fig. 8.1 (KE_max vs frequency), state the physical quantity represented by the gradient of the line.
State the physical quantity represented by the y-intercept of the extrapolated line in Fig. 8.1.
Show that the momentum p of a photon with wavelength λ is p = h/λ.
Use (a)(i) to show that a photon with momentum 9.5×10^–28 N s is red light.
A red-light beam (intensity 160 W m–2, area 2.5×10^–6 m^2) reflects from a plane mirror; photon momentum is 9.5×10^–28 N s. Show that photons incident per second = 1.4×10^15 s–1.
Use (b)(i) to determine the pressure exerted by the light on the mirror.
Beam is replaced by blue light of the same intensity. Suggest and explain whether the pressure is less than, the same as, or greater than for red light.
White light passes through a cloud of cool gas; the transmitted spectrum shows dark lines. Explain why these dark lines occur.
For an isolated hydrogen atom, wavelengths for transitions to n = 2 are 412, 435, 488, 658 nm; E2 = −3.40 eV. Calculate the energy, in J, of level n = 3.
The lowest four energy levels of an isolated atom are shown. Explain, with reference to photons, why each transition corresponds to a single frequency of electromagnetic radiation.
On the emission spectrum axis, draw and label line A for the transition n = 2 → n = 1.
On the same axis, draw and label line B for the transition n = 3 → n = 2.
The frequency of line A is fA and of line B is fB. The ground-state energy is E1. Determine an expression, in terms of fA, fB, E1 and Planck’s constant h, for the energy E3 of the level n = 3.
State what is meant by the de Broglie wavelength.
Electrons accelerated to a graphite crystal form a pattern on a fluorescent screen (Fig. 7.2). State the name of the phenomenon demonstrated by the pattern.
Explain what can be concluded from the pattern about the nature of electrons.
The accelerating p.d. is increased. On Fig. 7.3, sketch the new pattern seen on the screen.
Explain, with reference to the de Broglie wavelength, the change in the pattern when the accelerating p.d. is increased.
Describe how reflected ultrasound pulses may be used to obtain diagnostic information about internal structures.
Define specific acoustic impedance of a medium.
Using Table 10.1 (water: ρ = 1000 kg m–3, c = 1420 m s–1; glass: ρ = 2500 kg m–3, c = 4560 m s–1), determine the intensity reflection coefficient for ultrasound at a water–glass boundary.
State what is meant by a photon.
In the X-ray tube of Fig. 8.1, state the name of the particles that are accelerated from the filament to the target.
On Fig. 8.1, label terminals X and Y with + and − to indicate the polarity of the high voltage.
For an accelerating voltage of 32 kV, determine the maximum energy, in MeV, of an X-ray photon produced at the target.
Determine the maximum momentum of an X-ray photon produced at the target.
Determine the minimum wavelength of X-rays produced at the target.
Explain why X-rays can be used to produce images of internal body structures that have good contrast.
Electrons accelerated through 84 kV strike a metal target and produce X-rays. Calculate the minimum wavelength of the X-rays.
Melting points: copper 1090 °C, tungsten 3420 °C. Suggest why the target is tungsten rather than copper.

An X-ray beam passes normally through a slab comprising soft tissue (thickness x) and bone (thickness x). With μ_soft = 0.22 cm–1 and μ_bone = 3.0 cm–1, the transmitted intensity is 13% of the incident. Determine x in cm.
Define the specific acoustic impedance of a medium.
Using Z_soft = 1.7×10^6 kg m–2 s–1 and Z_bone = 7.8×10^6 kg m–2 s–1, calculate the percentage intensity of ultrasound transmitted at a soft-tissue/bone boundary.
For the sample in Fig. 9.1, suggest two reasons why the transmitted ultrasound intensity is less than the answer in (c)(ii).
Ultrasound and X-rays in medical diagnosis. Complete a table for each: method of production; whether the detected wave used for imaging is the absorbed, reflected, or transmitted wave.
For one wave type in tissue, intensity is 72% of initial after 6.2 cm. Calculate the linear attenuation coefficient μ (cm⁻¹).
Another wave of the same type traverses 9.3 cm of the same tissue. Calculate the percentage of the initial intensity that is attenuated.

A student investigates standing waves in water using the arrangement in Fig. 2.1. It is suggested that f and d are related by v/f = 4(d + k), where v is the speed of sound in water and k is a constant. A graph is plotted of d on the y-axis against 1/f on the x-axis. Determine expressions for the gradient and the y-intercept.
Values of f, d1 and d2 are given in Table 2.1. Calculate and record values of 1/f / 10^–3 Hz^–1 and d / cm in Table 2.1. Include the absolute uncertainties in d.
Plot a graph of d / cm against 1/f / 10^–3 Hz^–1. Include error bars for d.
Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines.
Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Determine the y-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of v and k. Include appropriate units and include the absolute uncertainties in your answers.
Determine the frequency f that gives a value of d of 30.0 cm.
Explain how ultrasound waves are detected.
An applied voltage V = V0 sin(ωt) drives a probe. The r.m.s. voltage is 66 V and the ultrasound frequency is 4.3 MHz. Determine V0.
Determine ω.
Table 9.1 lists density, speed and specific acoustic impedance for air and soft tissue (one column blank). Determine the unit for specific acoustic impedance values.
Calculate the density of soft tissue.
Use Table 9.1 to explain why ultrasound cannot produce an image inside an air-filled cavity such as the lungs.
In an X-ray tube for medical diagnosis, charged particles are accelerated towards a metal target by an applied p.d. (i) State the charged particles that are accelerated.
(ii) Explain how X-rays are produced at the metal target.
(iii) Calculate the minimum wavelength of X-rays produced when the applied p.d. is 5.80 kV.
X-rays pass through a medium with attenuation coefficient 1.4 cm^–1. Calculate the percentage of X-ray energy absorbed by a 2.8 cm thickness of the medium.
Table 8.1 lists density and speed of sound for air, gel and tissue. Show that the specific acoustic impedance of gel is 1.68 × 10^6 kg m–2 s–1.
Complete Table 8.1 by calculating the missing values to three significant figures.
Calculate the intensity reflection coefficient at an air–tissue boundary.
Calculate the intensity reflection coefficient at a gel–tissue boundary.
Use your answers in (b) to explain why gel is applied to the skin during ultrasound scanning.
Radioactive decay is random and spontaneous. State what is meant by random.
State what is meant by spontaneous.
Define half-life.
Using Table 9.1 (binding energy per nucleon for 193Po, 189Pb and 4He), determine the energy released (eV) when 193Po → 189Pb + α.
From the plot of ln(N/N0) vs t (Fig. 9.1), state the name of the quantity represented by the magnitude of the gradient.
Use Fig. 9.1 to determine the half-life, in ms, of polonium-193.
In PET scanning, state what happens to the positrons emitted by the tracer.
Explain why a tracer with a half-life of approximately 2 hours is suitable.
Radioactive decay is both random and spontaneous. State what is meant by random.
State what is meant by spontaneous.
State one piece of evidence for the random nature of decay.
Describe the differences between nuclear fission and nuclear fusion.
With reference to the variation of binding energy per nucleon with nucleon number, explain why both nuclear fission and nuclear fusion result in a release of energy.
Fluorine-18 decays by β+ emission (half-life 110 min). State the name of the β+ particle.
Show that the decay constant of fluorine-18 is 1.05 × 10^–4 s^–1.
Determine the activity of 2.1 × 10^–12 kg of fluorine-18.
A small sample of fluorine-18 injected into the body acts as a tracer. Describe how interaction of a β+ particle with an electron enables image formation for medical imaging.
Suggest why a half-life of 110 minutes is suitable for a nuclide used as a tracer in medical diagnosis.
State what is meant by the binding energy of a nucleus.
Using Table 9.1 (masses: proton 1.007 276 u, neutron 1.008 665 u, 212Po nucleus 211.942 749 u), determine the mass defect Δm in kg.
Determine the binding energy of the 212Po nucleus.
Determine the binding energy per nucleon.
On Fig. 9.1, sketch binding energy per nucleon versus nucleon number A for 1 ≤ A ≤ 250.
On your curve, mark with X the approximate position of polonium-212.
Polonium-212 undergoes alpha-decay. Suggest and explain, with reference to Fig. 9.1, why its alpha-decay results in a release of energy.
Define half-life of a radioactive isotope.
For Fig. 9.1, state the name of the quantity represented by the magnitude of the gradient of line X.
State three conclusions about X or Y that may be drawn from Fig. 9.1. The conclusions may be qualitative or quantitative.
The mass of radioactive isotope X is 7.3 × 10^–4 kg at t = 0. Determine the nucleon number of isotope X.
State what is meant by the binding energy of a nucleus.
In the fission 235/92U + 1/0n → 142/54Xe + 90/38Sr + neutrons, determine the number of neutrons produced.
Binding energies per nucleon: U-235 (7.59 MeV), Xe-142 (8.37 MeV), Sr-90 (8.72 MeV). Calculate the energy released (MeV) by fission of one U-235 nucleus.
Xenon-142 is unstable whereas xenon-132 is stable. Suggest a reason why xenon-142 is unstable.
Xe-142 decays to Cs-142. A sample initially pure Xe-142 has, after 6.0 s, a ratio (decayed nuclei : undecayed nuclei) of 3:1. Calculate the half-life of Xe-142, showing working.
State what is meant by a tracer.
Fluorine-18 decays according to ¹⁸₉F → ⁸O + X. State the symbol for X and the values of P, Q and R in the given notation.
Explain how the decay of fluorine-18 results in gamma-ray photons leaving the body in PET scanning.
Explain how detection of these gamma photons is used to produce an image of the tissue being examined.
Half-life of ¹⁸F is T. For injected amount of substance n, determine an expression for the initial rate R0 of gamma-ray production in terms of n, T and Avogadro constant NA.
On Fig. 9.1, sketch the variation with time t of R, marking R0 and T.
State what is meant by nuclear fusion.
On Fig. 9.1, sketch binding energy per nucleon vs nucleon number A for 1 ≤ A ≤ 250.
On your curve, label a point X that could represent a nucleus that undergoes alpha-decay.
On your curve, label a point Y that could represent a nucleus that undergoes nuclear fusion.

A nucleus Z undergoes fission to form 93_38Sr and 139_54Xe plus two neutrons. Table 9.1 gives BE of 93_38Sr and 139_54Xe. Fission of 1.00 mol of Z releases 1.77×10^13 J. Determine the binding energy per nucleon of Z in MeV.
Plutonium-238 undergoes α-decay. Complete: ²³⁸₉₄Pu → ______ + ______α.
A space-probe power source contains 0.874 kg of ²³⁸Pu. Each decay releases 5.59 MeV; half-life = 87.7 years. Calculate the initial number N₀ of nuclei.
Determine the initial activity of the source. Give a unit with your answer.
Use (b)(ii) and 5.59 MeV per decay to determine the initial power output.
The probe functions until power falls to 65.3% of the initial value. Calculate the operating time in years.
An alternative is ²¹⁰Po (half-life 0.378 years). For the same initial power, mass needed is 3.37 g. Suggest one advantage and one disadvantage of using ²¹⁰Po.
Define mass defect.
Given mass defects for ²¹H, ³¹H and ⁴₂He, a stellar fusion process is ²¹H + ³¹H → ⁴₂He + X where X has no mass defect. (i) State the name of particle X.
(ii) Show that the energy released when one nucleus of ⁴₂He is formed in this reaction is 2.8 × 10^−12 J.
A star has radius 2.3 × 10^9 m and luminosity 1.4 × 10^28 W. Assume all radiated energy comes from formation of ⁴₂He. Determine the mass of ⁴₂He produced per unit time.
(ii) Determine the surface temperature of the star.
Define half-life.
A sample contains N0 nuclei of carbon-11 and no other nuclei at t = 0. On Fig. 9.1, sketch the variation with t of the number of boron-11 nuclei in the sample.
Explain, with reference to the random nature of radioactive decay, why the activity of the carbon-11 sample decreases with time.
State, with reasons, whether a detector placed near the sample indicates a measured count rate that is less than, the same as, or greater than the activity of the sample.
State what is meant by the luminosity of a star.
Explain how standard candles are used to determine the distance to a galaxy.
The Sun rotates with period 2.07 × 10^6 s. Using Fig. 10.1 and the data, show that the Sun’s radius is 6.93 × 10^8 m.
State and explain how the expected wavelength of the light observed from Z compares with the emitted wavelength.
The luminosity of the Sun is 3.8 × 10^26 W. Use your result in (b)(i) to calculate the surface temperature of the Sun.
Define gravitational field.
For x = 1.47 × 10^11 m, calculate the gravitational field strength g due to the Sun.
Determine the gravitational potential energy EP of the probe at this position.
Show that, for any particular value of x, g and the radiant flux intensity F satisfy g = (4πGM/L) F.
From Fig. 2.1 (g versus F), determine a value for the luminosity L of the Sun. Give a unit.
Use your answer in (c)(ii) to determine the radius r of the Sun.
Explain how redshift leads to the idea that the Universe is expanding.

A distant galaxy has luminosity 1.90 × 10^36 W. Its emission line X is 658 nm in the rest frame. Observed on Earth: radiant flux intensity 8.42 × 10^–16 W m^–2 and line X at 726 nm. Determine the distance d of the galaxy from Earth.
Using the shift of line X to 726 nm, determine the speed v of the galaxy relative to Earth.
Many galaxies provide pairs of (d, v). On Fig. 10.1, sketch the variation of v with d.
State the name of the quantity represented by the gradient of the line in Fig. 10.1.

Part of the hydrogen emission spectrum from a star in a distant galaxy is shown (Fig. 8.1). The galaxy recedes at 6.2 × 10^6 m s–1. Explain how the line positions seen by an observer on Earth differ from those in Fig. 8.1.
On Fig. 8.1, draw the three lines in possible positions as seen by the observer.
The lines correspond to transitions to –3.40 eV. One line has wavelength 488 nm. Calculate the photon energy.
Determine the energy (in eV) of the upper level from which the transition originates for the 488 nm line.
Determine the wavelength, in nm, of this radiation as detected by the observer on Earth.
Given H0 = 2.3 × 10^–18 s–1, determine the distance of the galaxy from Earth.
State what is meant by the luminosity of a star.
Explain how a standard candle in a distant galaxy can be used to determine the distance of the galaxy from an observer.
The Sun has radius 6.96 × 10^8 m and surface temperature 5780 K; peak intensity at 501 nm. Calculate the luminosity of the Sun. Give a unit.
Another star emits radiation with peak intensity at 624 nm. Determine the surface temperature of this star.
The Sun has surface temperature 5780 K and luminosity 3.85 × 10^26 W. Calculate the Sun’s radius.
At a distance of 1.50 × 10^11 m from the Sun, calculate the radiant flux intensity F at Earth and give a unit.
Another star has the same radius as the Sun but lower surface temperature. On given axes, sketch intensity vs wavelength for this star compared with the Sun.

The Sun’s visible emission spectrum has prominent lines at 397, 410, 434, 486 and 656 nm. A galaxy in Corona Borealis is moving away from Earth. On axes, sketch the spectrum observed from a star in that galaxy.
The galaxy’s recession speed is 21 400 km s–1. Using (b)(i), calculate the observed wavelength (nm) of the lowest visible-energy emission for that star.
That observed wavelength is used to estimate the star’s surface temperature, but the value is inaccurate. State and explain whether the estimated temperature is too high or too low.
tags: Effect of redshift on Wien estimate

questions.question_text: State Wien’s displacement law, identifying any symbols used.
Define a standard candle.
State why the radiation from the observed star is redshifted.

A student estimates surface temperature (Wien), distance (standard candle), and radius (Stefan–Boltzmann) but does not correct for redshift. In Table 10.1, tick for each quantity (wavelength, surface temperature, distance, radius) whether the student’s uncorrected value is too low, the same, or too high compared with the true value.
Give two reasons why some stars appear brighter than others.
State what is meant by a standard candle.
A spectral line from a star is observed at 660.9 nm (laboratory value 656.3 nm). Show that the speed relative to Earth is 2.1 × 10^6 m s^−1.
Using H0 = 2.3 × 10^−18 s^−1, calculate the distance to the star.
State and explain what can be concluded about the Universe based on this change in observed wavelength.
State Hubble’s law and identify any symbols used.
A star of luminosity 3.8 × 10^31 W is at a distance of 1.8 × 10^24 m from Earth. Calculate the radiant flux intensity at the Earth.
A spectral line from the galaxy has rest wavelength 486 nm, observed at 492 nm on Earth. Explain why the observed wavelength differs from the emitted wavelength.
Determine a value for the Hubble constant H0.
